required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: "Cataract Surgery in Eyes With Epiretinal Membrane"
clinical_study.official_title: "Retinal Thickness Change Following Cataract Surgery in Eyes With Epiretinal Membrane"

lead_sponsor.agency: St John of God Hospital, Vienna

clinical_study.source: St John of God Hospital, Vienna

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of the study is to evaluate retinal thickness change and the occurrence of central structural retinal changes after uneventful small-incision cataract surgery in eyes with asymptomatic early stages of epiretinal membrane.

detailed_description.textblock: Optical coherence tomography (OCT) is nowadays used in daily clinical practice and has become a helpful tool for detection of macular changes also in presence of opacification of the lens before cataract surgery. Using recent high-resolution OCT technology, early stages of epiretinal membranes can easily be detected and analysed. Since cataract surgery is one of the most frequently performed operations worldwide, this study was aimed to investigate the influence of uncomplicated cataract surgery on central retinal thickness and the incidence of structural and morphological macular changes after surgery in eyes with asymptomatic epiretinal membrane.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline central macular thickness at 3 months

study_pop.textblock: Thirty patients with visually compromising cataract and asymptomatic epiretinal membrane (ERM group) and 15 consecutive eyes with senile cataract with a healthy macula (control group) were included.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- visually compromising cataract and asymptomatic early stages of epiretinal membrane with no structural changes such as cysts or photoreceptor distribution in optical coherence tomography.
Exclusion Criteria:
- visual impairment or metamorphopsia due to epiretinal membrane
- history of branch retinal vein occlusion
- central retinal vein occlusion
- wet or dry macular degeneration
- diabetic retinopathy
- uveitis or other inflammatory eye disease.

overall_official.affiliation: St John of God Hospital, Vienna
St John of God Hospital, Vienna

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: St John of God Hospital, Vienna
